Award.AwardTitle: Support for International Ocean Science Activities Through the Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
Support for the international oceanographic activities of the Scientific Committee on Oceanic Research (SCOR) that are relevant to U.S. interests in marine sciences and the Division of Ocean Sciences. Support of these international activities through SCOR began in 1987. The SCOR provides an international, interdisciplinary, non-governmental focus for ocean research and makes it possible for national ocean science communities to (1) participate in international research projects, (2) identify important ocean science issues and create working groups to address the issues, and (3) participate in capacity-building activities (40% of SCOR national committees are based in developing countries). Funding in this request provides partial support for SCOR Working Group activities, and international projects such as International Ocean Carbon Coordination Project (IOCCP), GlobalHAB, Surface Ocean - Lower Atmosphere Study (SOLAS), Integrated Marine Biogeochemistry and Ecosystem Research (IMBER), and GEOTRACES. These activities also are supported by other international and national sponsors.

These major programs have origins in US and have turned to SCOR to provide a forum for international planning and coordination. SCOR's impact has and will continue to be evident in the standardization of measurement protocols, sharing of data, coordination of ship time, and the enlargement of field studies which would be impossible without international coordination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this grant was to support activities to stimulate international cooperation in ocean science to increase the foundation of knowledge needed to understand the ocean and its processes. This grant helps support one of the few organizations that brings togehter multinational groups of scientists to provide important information about the ocean. Each project includes U.S. scientists.

The work funded included international research projects aimed at describing the distributions of trace elements and isotopes in the ocean, understanding how the boundary between the ocean and atmosphere affects the movement of gases and materials across the boundary, understanding how ocean biological cycles work, and studying how harmful algae blooms form and can be managed. These research projects are managed by the top experts on their topics, with regular rotations of group membership to ensure younger scientists become involved.

The grant also supported the work of more than 15 working groups, which are small groups of experts formed to synthesize data from past observations of the ocean to make these observations more widely available; intercalibrate measurements made in different laboratories to make the measurements comparable; recommend new methods for studying ocean chemistry and biology; provide manuals to guide experiments and observations of various types; improve instrumentation for studying the ocean; develop online resources for understanding ocean chemistry;  and identify priorities for future ocean research. These groups usually complete their work in 3-5 years and then are disbanded, so that the range of topics covered by the groups is regularly renewed.

The grant also supported the compilation of ocean carbon data to make it more accessible, develop standards for observing ocean carbon and ocean acidification, and incorporation of instruments to measure ocean carbon and other biologically important elements into the Global Ocean Observing System. The grant supported the continued development and implementation of the Southern Ocean Observing System.
